user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimerGetInfo(osal_id_t timer_id, OS_timer_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timecb_internal_record_t *  timecb;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timecb_table, token);
        timecb   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timecb_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, timecb->timebase_token);

        strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1);
        timer_prop->creator       = record->creator;
        timer_prop->interval_time = (uint32)timecb->interval_time;
        timer_prop->accuracy      = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimerGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
osal_id_t OS_TaskGetId_Impl(void)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t self_record;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    self_record.opaque_arg = pthread_getspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey);

    return self_record.id;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB 0x09
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_timecb_table
...
OS_timecb_internal_record_t OS_timecb_table[OS_MAX_TIMERS]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    uint32    start_time;
    uint32    interval_time;
    uint32    accuracy;
} OS_timer_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char              timer_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    uint32            flags;
    OS_object_token_t timebase_token;
    osal_id_t         prev_cb;
    osal_id_t         next_cb;
    uint32            backlog_resets;
    int32             wait_time;
    int32             interval_time;
    OS_ArgCallback_t  callback_ptr;
    void *            callback_arg;
} OS_timecb_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Selected fragments are those that can cause portions of the function to be not executed (or to perform potentially unsafe lookups) and therefore should be investigated for possible unreachable-code or related validity issues. Other lines in the function do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 because:

- The memset(timer_prop, 0, ...) is a straightforward initialization and is executed unless the function returns earlier (the early return point is already included as suspicious). It does not itself create unreachable code.

- The assignments after a successful object lookup (inside the reported if-block) are conditionally reachable only when OS_ObjectIdGetById returns OS_SUCCESS; that conditional branch is intentional and is already reported for inspection. The presence of the conditional itself is not a violation unless the condition is statically always false/true, which requires inspecting the reported call(s).

- The strncpy usage appears preceded by memset of the target structure, which preserves termination even when using sizeof(...) - 1; this is a runtime safety detail rather than a static unreachable-code concern.

- Helper functions/macros (OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl, OS_TaskGetId_Impl, OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, OS_ObjectIdRelease, BUGCHECK via OS_CHECK_POINTER) are external behaviors that determine reachability; their invocation points are reported above where they affect control flow. Investigating those reported call sites is sufficient to determine whether code is actually unreachable.
